reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Addressing the life-sustaining needs of vulnerable conflict-affected communities in North-East Syria

description.narrative: Close to eight years into the crisis, the scale, severity, and complexity of needs across Syria remain staggering in their magnitude and severity. The conflict is the main driver of the humanitarian needs. As per the last estimations, 13 million people remain in need of humanitarian assistance with 5.2 million of them facing acute needs. 6.2 million are protractedly internally displaced. Until July 2018, an estimated 90,000 people remain displaced across North East Syria (NES) during the current year, with more than 50% (53,399) residing in camps of informal sites. The communities of Southern-Hassakeh and Northern-Deir Ez Zor are among the most in need of humanitarian assistance, scoring between 3 and 5 in the Whole of Syria (Wos) Inter-sector Severity Categorization. Lack of basis service such as water and electricity supply, combined with open fights, remoteness of the areas, high concentration of IDPs, and the complexity in conducting cross-lines operations are the main factors that determine the severity of the needs. Action Against Hunger (referred as AAH) has been supporting vulnerable communities across NES in the past months through humanitarian programming, focusing mostly on WASH, FSL, and more recently in Shelter. The project seeks to ensure the continuation of life-sustaining WASH responses in the vulnerable communities of Southern-Hassakeh and Northern-Deir Ez Zor, following a two-pronged strategy. The first pillar seeks to protect a health and hygienic environment in IDPs settings, namely Areesheh camp. The project envisages three activities – waste-water disposal, solid waste management, and latrines cleaniless-, aiming at providing continuation of the services already in place. The second pillar seeks to ensure access to safe water through water trucking service to overburdened host and returnees’ communities in the nearby areas (Areesheh, Markada, Elwet Eldisheisha and Sur). In addition to these elements, the project builds on a third pillar. Coordination with United Nations (UN) agencies and National Non-Governmental Organizations (NNGOs) operating in the IDPs camp as well as WASH Sector Partners is transversal in the project-strategy. As outcome, the project seeks to reduce the vulnerability of 46,199 individuals. Following the Protection Cluster recommendations, beneficiaries-groups prioritized by this project are IDPs transiting and staying in last resort camps/sites (Areesheh) and overburdened host communities and returnees. As well, the proposed project mainstreams and incorporates protection principles in the activities to promote meaningful access, safety and dignity. Despite the challenging environment, and thanks to its effective access strategy, AAH has full-access to the targeted areas and has the capacity in place to start the operations according to the work-plan set through direct-implementation.
